questions.text: The chest x-ray of the patient below is showing a d-shaped shadow in the left-MID zone consistent with empyema. What will you do next?

options.label: A
options.text: Tube is put on suction and flushed regularly

questions.correct_answer: A. Tube is put on suction and flushed regularly
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tube is put on suction and flushed regularly Empyema is associated with increased morbidity and mortality unless interventions are done immediately .in this chest x-ray intercostal drain is put but the loculated pus still remains. Hence the next step is to clear the pus by putting t he tube on suction and flushing regularly with 20 ml of normal saline

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:: B. Start empirical antibiotics since the chest x-ray shows loculations, the main aim is to remove the remaining pus first Option: C . Start fibrinolytic therapy-fibrinolytic therapy has no use in the case of empyema as there is no benefit Option: D . Surgical intervention done surgical intervention is done only when there is a break of adhesions or there is any gross thickening of visceral pleura and also when there is the development of bronchopleural fistula as these are the surgical indications

Which of the following is not a feature of the given condition?

questions.text: A 75-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive shortness of breath and chronic cough. On examination, he has a barrel-shaped chest and pursed lip breathing. Hyperresonance and inspiratory wheezes are heard. Pulmonary functions are likely to reveal all of the following except;

options.label: B
options.text: Increased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide The given clinical diagnosis is suggestive of COPD and the underlying pathological change is likely to be emphysema . It is associated with a decreased DLCO Emphysema is defined pathologically as the abnormal and permanent dilatation of airways distal to the terminal bronchiole along with the destruction of their walls. This leads to hyperinflation due to air trapping and impaired diffusion of gases . Due to the destruction of the walls of alveoli, there is decreased surface area which results in decreased DLCO.

Highyeild:

Pulmonary function tests in COPD TLC: Normal or increased FEV1: Decreased FVC: Decreased FEV1/FVC: Decreased DLCO: Decreased Diseases associated with lowered DLCO Emphysema Interstitial lung diseas e Primary pulmonary hypertension

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options: - Option: A . Decreased forced vital capacity is seen in COPD and is a true statement Option: C. Total lung capacity seen is normal or increased Option: D . FEV1/FVC: Decreased is seen in COPD and is true

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is admitted to ICU with a 4-day history of increasing shortness of breath and cough with copious sputum. She is a known COPD with a fev1 of 42%. On presentation, she has room air blood gas with a pH of 7.26, paco2 of 78 mmHg and paO2 of 50 mmHg. she is in obvious respiratory distress with the use of accessory muscles and retractions. Breath sounds are quiet with diffuse expiratory wheezing and rhonchi. Which of the following therapies has been demonstrated to have the greatest reduction in the mortality rate for these patients?

options.label: C
options.text: Early administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics with coverage of p. aeruginosa

options.label: D
options.text: Use of NIPPV (non-invasive positive pressure ventilation)

questions.correct_answer: D. Use of NIPPV (non-invasive positive pressure ventilation)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Use of NIPPV (non-invasive positive pressure ventilation) Acute exacerbation of COPD is marked by an increase in dyspnea, sputum and change in sputum colou in patients with hypercarbic respiratory failure in the setting of acute exacerbation. the treatment that demonstrated the strongest reduction in mortality is NIPPV when compared to mechanical ventilation. antibiotics, bronchodilators and glucocorticoids are used in acute exacerbation but do not have mortality benefits. n o benefit is demonstrated for iv or oral corticosteroids. Likewise, the choice of antibiotic should be based on local susceptibility patterns. Therefore, the need for broad-spectrum antibiotics that cover pseudomonas is not indicated

questions.text: A 65-year-old with a long history of smoking comes with a 4-month history of progressive sob, and dyspnea on exertion. he denies fever, chest pain or hemoptysis. he has a daily cough of 3 to 6 tablespoons of yellow phlegm. Physical examination is notable for normal vital signs, a prolonged expiratory phase, scattered rhonchi, elevated JVP and moderate pedal edema. hematocrit is 49%. Which of the following therapies is likely to prolong his survival?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxygen

Highyeild:

The only therapy that has proven to improve survival in COPD patients are smoking cessation, oxygen in patients with resting hypoxemia, and lung volume reduction surgery because oxygenation will treat hypoxemia in COPD patients. This patient probably has resting hypoxemia resulting from the presence of elevated JVP, pedal edema and elevated hematocrit. theophylline has been shown to increase exercise tolerance in patients with COPD. Oral glucocorticoids are not indicated in the absence of acute exacerbation. Atenolol and enalapril have no role in copd.

questions.text: A 64-year-old chronic smoker presents with gradual worsening of shortness of breath and chronic cough. On examination, there is a bilateral extensive wheeze. Pulmonary function test reveals fev1/fvc<0. 7. Which among the following is true regarding the condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Fev1 improves on inhalation of albuterol

options.label: D
options.text: There is abnormal permanent bronchial dilatation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

V/q is mismatched The above clinical scenario is suggestive of COPD. There is always a v/q mismatch in obstructive lung disease due to premature closure of airways.

questions.text: Common obstructive lung diseases include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, and bronchiectasis. COPD has two major clinicopathologic manifestations, emphysema and chronic bronchitis. The most common type of respiratory failure most appropriately associated with severe COPD is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both type 1 and type 2 Respiratory failure is a syndrome in which the respiratory system fails in one or both of its gas exchange functions: oxygenation and carbon dioxide elimination.

Highyeild:

Chronic bronchitis is a dysfunction of bronchioles , so it resembles more to type 2 respiratory failure. Severe COPD can be put into both type 1 and type 2 respiratory failure. Type 3 respiratory failure (Option: 3) - post-operative or due to anaesthesia. Here (A - a)O2 is increased. Type 4 respiratory failure is due t o hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles. COPD is an obstructive disease, so it should be kept in type 2 respiratory failure. If the Option: of both type 1 and type 2 is given, it should be preferred, because emphysema causes a reduction in surface area for ventilation and in turn causes type 1 RF.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options: - Option: A - Hypoxemic respiratory failure (type I) - is characterized by an arterial oxygen tension (PaO2) lower than 60 mm Hg with a normal or low arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2). This is the most common form of respiratory failure Some examples of type I respiratory failure are cardiogenic or noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, pneumonia, pulmonary haemorrhage and COPD. Option: B - Hypercapnic respiratory failure (type II) - is characterized by a PaCO2 higher than 50 mm Hg. Hypoxemia is common in patients with hypercapnic respiratory failure who are breathing room air Option:. C - Type 3 respiratory failure (Option: 3) - post-operative or due to anaesthesia. Common etiologies include drug overdose, neuromuscular disease, chest wall abnormalities, and severe airway disorders (eg, asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD]

Extraedge:

Diseases of the alveoli are characterized by diffuse alveolar filling, frequently resulting in hypoxemic respiratory failure, although hypercapnia may complicate the clinical picture. Although emphysema resembles type 1 respiratory failure because it is a dysfunction of the But A number of factors contribute to airway obstruction in emphysema. Small airways are normally held open by the elastic recoil of the lung parenchyma. The loss of elastic tissue in the walls of alveoli that surround respiratory bronchioles reduces radial traction, leading to the collapse of respiratory bronchioles during expiration and functional airflow obstruction in the absence of mechanical obstruction.

questions.text: Common obstructive lung diseases include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, and bronchiectasis. COPD has two major clinicopathologic manifestations, emphysema and chronic bronchitis, which are often found together in the same patient, almost certainly because they share the same major etiologic factor—cigarette smoking. Which of the following statement is NOT correct with respect to chronic bronchitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic bronchitis is defined clinically as persistent cough with sputum production for at least 3 months in at least 2 consecutive years in the absence of any other identifiable cause

options.label: B
options.text: The earliest feature of chronic bronchitis is hypersecretion of mucus in the large airways

options.label: C
options.text: Inhalants that induce chronic bronchitis cause cellular damage, eliciting both acute and chronic inflammatory responses involving neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages

options.label: D
options.text: Infections can initiate chronic bronchitis, but may not be critical in producing acute exacerbations

questions.correct_answer: D. Infections can initiate chronic bronchitis, but may not be critical in producing acute exacerbations
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Infections can initiate chronic bronchitis, but may not be critical in producing acute exacerbations. The correct statement will be - Infection does not initiate chronic bronchitis but is probably significant in maintaining it and may be critical in producing acute exacerbations.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options: - Option: A . is true, it is the classic pathological definition of chronic bronchitis. Option: B. is true, The earliest feature of chronic bronchitis is hypersecretion of mucus in the large airways , associated with enlargement of the submucosal glands in the trachea and bronchi. The basis for mucus hypersecretion is incompletely understood, but it appears to involve inflammatory mediators such as histamine and IL-13. Option: C. is true, Inhalants that induce chronic bronchitis cause cellular damage, eliciting both acute and chronic inflammatory responses involving neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages. Long-standing inflammation and accompanying fibrosis involving small airways (small bronchi and bronchioles, less than 2 to 3 mm in diameter) can also lead to chronic airway obstruction.

questions.text: Chronic bronchitis is associated with progressive lung dysfunction, which may be so severe as to lead to hypoxemia, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale. Grossly, there is hyperemia, swelling, and edema of the mucous membranes, frequently accompanied by excessive mucinous or mucopurulent secretions. The most striking change is an increase in the size of the mucous glands. This increase can be mathematically measured by Reid Index using A, B, C and D. Identify the correct mathematical expression for the Reid Index.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reid Index = BC/ AD The Reid index is a pathological measurement of mucosal gland proliferation in chronic bronchitis. It is assessed by comparing the thickness of the mucous glandular tissue versus the distance from the epithelium to the level of cartilage. An index of < 0.4 is considered to be within normal limits.

Highyeild:

Reid Index can be assessed by the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the cartilage. BC = mucous gland thickness AD = thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the cartilage So the correct expression for the Reid index will be BC / AD The Reid index (normally 0.4) is increased in chronic bronchitis , usually in proportion to the severity and duration of the disease.

Reid index is not equal to AC/AD and it is not equal to the distance between The basement membrane and the mucous gland by the distance between the basement membrane and the perichondrium

Extraedge:

Reid Index (normal) = 0.4 and not 0.6 [repeatedly asked question] The mucus plugging, inflammation, and fibrosis may lead to marked narrowing of bronchioles, and in the most severe cases, there may be the obliteration of the lumen due to fibrosis (bronchiolitis obliterans).
